review.title: An evaluative baseline for geo-semantic relatedness and similarity
review.abstract: In geographic information science and semantics, the computation of semantic similarity is widely recognised as key to supporting a vast number of tasks in information integration and retrieval. By contrast, the role of geo-semantic relatedness has been largely ignored. In natural language processing, semantic relatedness is often confused with the more specific semantic similarity. In this article, we discuss a notion of geo-semantic relatedness based on Lehrer's semantic fields, and we compare it with geo-semantic similarity. We then describe and validate the Geo Relatedness and Similarity Dataset (GeReSiD), a new open dataset designed to evaluate computational measures of geo-semantic relatedness and similarity. This dataset is larger than existing datasets of this kind, and includes 97 geographic terms combined into 50 term pairs rated by 203 human subjects. GeReSiD is available online and can be used as an evaluation baseline to determine empirically to what degree a given computational model approximates geo-semantic relatedness and similarity.

metadata.title: An Evaluative Baseline for Geo-Semantic Relatedness and Similarity

sections.text: Keywords geo-semantic relationship · geo-semantic similarity · gold standards · geo-semantics · cognitive plausibility · GeReSiD

sections.heading: 3 Semantic relatedness and similarity gold standards
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it will happen, until it does.

sections.heading: 4 Geo Relatedness and Similarity Dataset (GeReSiD)
sections.text: This section presents the Geo Relatedness and Similarity Dataset (GeReSiD), a dataset of human judgments that we have developed to provide a basic truth for the evaluation of computer-based references and similarity measurements. GeReSiD explicitly captures the difference between geo-semantic terms and similarity on a sample of geographical terms larger than existing similarity datasets examined in Section 3, including both natural and man-made terms. To ensure their validity as the gold standard, it focuses on a sample of distributed terms / similarities between geographical terms ranging from very high to very low terms. Section 4.1 accurately describes our methodology to provide guidelines for the construction of datasets to fathom the evaluation of geo-semantic relations and similarity measures.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this article, we discussed an idea of geo-semantic relationality based on the theory of semantic fields that compares it to the widely studied geo-semantic similarity. Despite the variety and importance of the computational metrics developed in natural language processing, the evaluation of such metrics remains a difficult and complex task [12]. In order to provide an evaluation baseline for geo-semantic research on relativity and similarity, we developed, collected and analyzed the Geo Relatedness and similarity Dataset (GeReSiD), which contains human judgments on semantic relationships and similarity that encompass 97 unique geographical terms. To enhance the usability and clarity of the datasets, the terms were assigned to the corresponding terms in Word- English.

metadata.abstractText: In geographic information science and semantics, the computation of semantic similarity is widely recognised as key to supporting a vast number of tasks in information integration and retrieval. By contrast, the role of geosemantic relatedness has been largely ignored. In natural language processing, semantic relatedness is often confused with the more specific semantic similarity. In this article, we discuss a notion of geo-semantic relatedness based on Lehrer’s semantic fields, and we compare it with geo-semantic similarity. We then describe and validate the Geo Relatedness and Similarity Dataset (GeReSiD), a new open dataset designed to evaluate computational measures of geo-semantic relatedness and similarity. This dataset is larger than existing datasets of this kind, and includes 97 geographic terms combined into 50 term pairs rated by 203 human subjects. GeReSiD is available online and can be used as an evaluation baseline to determine empirically to what degree a given computational model approximates geo-semantic relatedness and similarity.
